articles.title: From ancient temples to bomb craters: explore Laos’s layered history — in photos
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 February 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00330-4All-action archaeologist Daniel Davenport unpacks the country’s complex past from inside its vast national parks.
articles.content:
Hin Nam No National Protected Area is a natural wonder, located in south-central Laos on the border with Vietnam. The region was formed from an ocean floor during the Paleozoic era more than 400 million years ago. Its jagged karst peaks and ridges reach 300 metres in height and jut out of a flat plain of lush forest and winding rivers.

Last July, the area — which joins with Vietnam’s Phong Nha–Ke Bang National Park — was designated as the fourth UNESCO World Heritage site in Laos.

“It’s a stunningly beautiful landscape,” says Australian archaeologist Daniel Davenport as he speeds his battered Land Cruiser through muddy puddles. It’s also challenging terrain — especially during the wet season that lasts from May to October. Roads are swallowed by rivers, and are only passable by way of small ferries that barely accommodate Davenport’s vehicle.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the designation of Hin Nam No National Protected Area as a UNESCO World Heritage site, which is a significant conservation achievement with broad environmental and cultural impact. It focuses on preserving a unique natural landscape and its historical significance, benefiting both nature and society.
articles.personality_title: Laos’s Hin Nam No joins UNESCO heritage list, revealing nature and history
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Hin Nam No National Protected Area is a large natural park in south-central Laos, next to the border with Vietnam. It features tall, sharp limestone mountains formed over 400 million years ago and rich forests with winding rivers. 

**What happened** – In July 2025, Hin Nam No was officially named a UNESCO World Heritage site, making it Laos’s fourth site to earn this status. This recognition connects it with Vietnam’s nearby Phong Nha–Ke Bang National Park, creating a larger protected area across the two countries. Australian archaeologist Daniel Davenport has been exploring the site, sharing its beauty and challenges.

**Impact** – Being listed as a UNESCO World Heritage site means Hin Nam No is recognized worldwide for its unique natural beauty and important history. This helps protect the area from damage and encourages careful conservation. It also raises awareness of Laos’s rich natural and cultural heritage, attracting scientists and visitors interested in both nature and archaeology.

**What's next step** – With this new status, Laos and Vietnam will work together to manage and preserve the area. More research and tours are expected, helping people learn about the environment and history while supporting local communities through sustainable tourism.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Laos’s Hin Nam No National Protected Area gained UNESCO World Heritage status, highlighting its ancient landscapes and boosting efforts to protect its natural and historical treasures.
articles.personality_title_fr: Hin Nam No au Laos devient site du patrimoine mondial de l’UNESCO, révélant nature et histoire
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La zone protégée nationale de Hin Nam No est un grand parc naturel situé dans le centre-sud du Laos, à la frontière avec le Vietnam. Elle comprend de hautes montagnes calcaires formées il y a plus de 400 millions d’années, ainsi que des forêts denses et des rivières sinueuses.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En juillet 2025, Hin Nam No a été officiellement inscrite au patrimoine mondial de l’UNESCO, devenant ainsi le quatrième site lao à recevoir cette reconnaissance. Ce site rejoint le parc national Phong Nha–Ke Bang au Vietnam, créant une grande zone protégée transfrontalière. L’archéologue australien Daniel Davenport explore la région et partage sa beauté ainsi que ses défis.

**Impact** – Cette inscription signifie que Hin Nam No est reconnue mondialement pour sa beauté naturelle unique et son importance historique. Cela aide à protéger la région contre les dégâts et encourage la conservation. Cela fait aussi mieux connaître le riche patrimoine naturel et culturel du Laos, attirant chercheurs et visiteurs.

**Prochaine étape** – Grâce à ce nouveau statut, le Laos et le Vietnam vont collaborer pour gérer et préserver la zone. Davantage de recherches et de visites sont prévues, ce qui permettra d’apprendre sur l’environnement et l’histoire tout en soutenant les communautés locales via un tourisme durable.

**Une phrase clé** – La zone protégée nationale de Hin Nam No au Laos a obtenu le statut de patrimoine mondial de l’UNESCO, mettant en valeur ses paysages anciens et renforçant la protection de ses trésors naturels et historiques.

articles.title: Earth911 Inspiration: Waste Can End With You
articles.summary:
This week’s inspiration: “Waste starts with people and can end with you.” We can make...
The post Earth911 Inspiration: Waste Can End With You appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
This week’s inspiration: “Waste starts with people and can end with you.”

We can make changes to reduce our waste by precycling when we shop, reducing what we purchase, reusing items to get the most use out of them, and recycling when possible. But when we have items to throw away, please dispose of trash responsibly and don’t litter. Let’s reduce our waste and clean up our planet. It’s our only home.

Earth911 inspirations. Post them, share your desire to help people think of the planet first, every day. Click the poster to get a larger image.



Editor’s Note: This poster was originally published on March 12, 2021.
articles.reasoning: The article promotes actionable environmental responsibility by encouraging waste reduction through precycling, reusing, recycling, and proper disposal, which has broad significance for environmental conservation and public awareness.
articles.personality_title: Simple steps to reduce waste start with you
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Every day, people create a lot of waste that can harm the environment. Many organizations encourage ways to reduce this waste to keep our planet cleaner.

**What happened** – Earth911 shared a message reminding everyone that waste begins with people but can also end with each person’s choices. They suggest four actions: buying less (called precycling), reusing items, recycling when possible, and throwing away trash properly to avoid litter.

**Impact** – This message is important because it shows that each person’s actions matter in reducing waste. By following these simple steps, people can help keep the planet cleaner and reduce pollution. It also encourages people to think carefully about what they buy and use.

**What’s next step** – Earth911 encourages people to share this message with others and keep thinking about the planet every day. The hope is that more people will take responsibility and make better choices to reduce waste.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Reducing waste starts with small choices like buying less, reusing, recycling, and disposing of trash properly, and everyone can help make a difference.
